title: How to Fold an Origami Peacock

steps.title: Most origami paper is square, but you'll need a rectangle.
steps.content: Most origami paper is square, but you'll need a rectangle. You can either cut a sheet of square paper in half, or you can purchase rectangular origami paper. The dimensions don’t matter too much—just note that the smaller your sheet of paper is, the smaller your peacock will be in the end. [1] X Research source Pick any color paper that you’d like! Blue is a popular choice for peacocks, but you could go for red, pink, green, yellow, or any color of the rainbow.

steps.title: The goal is just to make a crease in the center.
steps.content: The goal is just to make a crease in the center. Set your paper out on a flat surface, then fold it in half. Use your fingers to press down on the crease, then unfold the paper again before moving on. [2] X Research source

steps.title: It will kind of look like a paper airplane.
steps.content: It will kind of look like a paper airplane. Fold the left corner in toward the center, then fold the right corner in to match. Press the creases down with your fingers, then fold both corners in again. [3] X Research source You’ll end up with a triangle-shaped paper that has a sharp point on one end.

steps.title: Flip the paper over so the folded parts touch the table.
steps.content: Flip the paper over so the folded parts touch the table. Then, bring the flat end of the triangle upward to meet the pointed end. Press down on the crease to make the fold stick. [4] X Research source It might help to push down on the crease with your fingernail.

steps.title: You’re creating the first fan fold in your peacock’s tail.
steps.content: You’re creating the first fan fold in your peacock’s tail. Grab the flat part of the triangle and fold it back, but leave about 1 ⁄ 4 in (0.64 cm) of paper on top of the pointed part. Press the crease down to really cement it into the paper and start the tail. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Time for more fan folds!
steps.content: Time for more fan folds! Alternate between folding forward and backward, making horizontal folds up the tail. When you reach the top, press all your folds down one more time to really cement them into the paper before letting go. [6] X Research source

steps.title: It’s time to create the peacock’s beak.
steps.content: It’s time to create the peacock’s beak. Grab the very tip of the pointed part and fold it down just slightly, enough to make a small beak at the head of your animal. Press the crease down to keep it in place and make a bird-like mouth. [7] X Research source It won’t look quite right at this step, so don’t worry—you still have more to do!

steps.title: Mark the head and neck of the peacock with this fold.
steps.content: Mark the head and neck of the peacock with this fold. Flip your paper so that the beak is facing you. Fold the pointed part of the triangle down about halfway so the head just touches the base of the tail. Press the crease down to differentiate between the body and the neck. [8] X Research source This fold will also help your peacock stand up on its own.

steps.title: Really make those feathers fan out.
steps.content: Really make those feathers fan out. Pick up your piece of paper and press down in the center of the tail with your thumb. Fold the entire peacock (body, tail, and head) in half around your finger, then press the fold together. [9] X Research source When the peacock springs back, you’ll be able to see the animal more clearly.

steps.title: Now you’re done!
steps.content: Now you’re done! Spend a few minutes making sure the tail in the back stands up straight and tall. Set your peacock down on the table and watch it stand up on its own to admire your creation. [10] X Research source If your peacock isn’t standing up, try folding the paper in half again to really crease that last fold.
